title: 110_s479
content: The Act titled the "Joshua Omvig Veterans Suicide Prevention Act" emphasizes the need for a comprehensive program to prevent suicide among veterans with PTSD. Congress recognizes the seriousness of the issue and urges the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to address the special needs of these veterans in the program. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to develop a program to reduce veteran suicide rates, including a mental health campaign targeting veterans of recent conflicts. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must implement a program to reduce veteran suicide rates, including mandatory training on suicide prevention for department employees and contractors interacting with veterans. Training will cover recognizing risk factors and crisis response protocols. The program includes outreach and education for veterans and families to eliminate stigmas, understand readjustment issues, identify mental health symptoms, and encourage seeking assistance. The program supports veterans in seeking assistance for mental health issues through peer counseling and outreach. Training is provided for peer counselors to identify suicide risk factors. The program offers peer support counseling as an additional service to existing mental health services for veterans. It encourages mental health assessments for veterans applying for benefits and provides referrals for counseling and treatment. Additionally, the program includes suicide prevention counselors. The program includes suicide prevention counselors at Department of Veterans Affairs medical facilities to engage in outreach to veterans and improve coordination of mental health care. Research on best practices for suicide prevention among veterans is also part of the program. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will develop a steering committee comprised of representatives from the National Institute of Mental Health, Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to advise on research for suicide prevention among veterans. The program will also provide referrals for substance abuse treatment for veterans showing signs of substance abuse. The program for suicide prevention among veterans includes 24-hour mental health care services, a toll-free telephone hotline for information and referrals, and other activities to reduce suicide incidence. Additionally, a report to Congress on suicide prevention programs and activities is required. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a report to Congress on programs to reduce veteran suicide within 90 days of this Act. The report will detail program implementation status, costs, and future plans for suicide prevention. Recommendations for legislative or administrative actions will also be included. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consult with key organizations to develop a plan to enhance suicide prevention programs within the Department.
